name: cognizable
content:
cognizable adjective
(LAW)
Add to word list
Add to word list
law
  specialized able to be judged by a court: The company has not violated any of your legally cognizable rights. We tell our clients to put their intentions and promises in writing, if they wish to make those legally cognisable.
More examplesFewer examplesIf someone who has been the victim of a cognizable offence gives information to the police, the police have a duty to put that information into writing.He has not suffered any cognisable damage as a result of the sale.

Crime - general words
cognizable adjective
(SENSES)
formal able to be seen or understood: Our politics is not dominated by any cognizable ideology, whichever party has a majority. The more external conditions affect our consciousness, the more easily cognisable they become.
